title: 104_s1236
content: The Act is titled the "National Commemorative Events Advisory Act" and includes findings. The "National Commemorative Events Advisory Act" finds that a commission should be established to efficiently review proposals for national commemorative events, saving time and resources for Congress. The commission reviews proposals for national commemorative events from various groups. The commission reviews proposals for national commemorative events from various groups. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP. The President's Advisory Commission on National Commemorative Events is established with 11 members appointed by different officials, all of whom must be U.S. citizens. Members appointed by the President should represent a wide range of backgrounds. The President's Advisory Commission on National Commemorative Events consists of 11 members who must be U.S. citizens. Members should have diverse educational, geographical, and professional backgrounds, and cannot be Members of Congress. Each member is appointed for a 2-year term, with some exceptions for initial appointments. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment process. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed for 2-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairman is designated by the President and serves a 2-year term. A quorum of 6 members is required for recommendations. Meetings are held quarterly in Washington, D.C. Members are paid the daily equivalent of GS-15 pay. Members of the Commission, including full-time officers or employees of the United States or Members of Congress, are paid the daily equivalent of GS-15 pay. They are also allowed travel expenses, including a per diem allowance, while performing services for the Commission. SEC. 4. STAFF. The Commission may not employ staff personnel. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. SEC. 5. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. SEC. 5. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, accept gifts, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services. The Commission establishes criteria for recommending national commemorative events to the President, reviews proposals, and issues recommendations with explanations. It does not recommend events commemorating commercial entities. The Commission establishes criteria for recommending national commemorative events to the President, excluding events commemorating commercial entities. Nonpermanent designations for commemorating events must not start more than 1 year after designation and cannot be duplicated within the same calendar year. The Act will be effective on January 1, 1996. The Commission will be appointed within 90 days after the Act's effective date and will terminate 5 years after its first meeting.
